head.note: This manuscript record does not have a summary list of contents. For composite manuscripts, the list of contents can be found under each individual part.

listRelation.desc: This composite manuscript consists of 6 distinct parts:

altIdentifier.collection: William Wright, Catalogue of the Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838
William Wright, Catalogue of the Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

head.note: This manuscript contains: The first two Gospels, according to the Peshitta version. In total, including sub-sections, this manuscript contains 3 items.

listRelation.desc: This unit is a part of a composite manuscript:

msItem.title: The first two Gospels, according to the Peshitta version

physDesc.p: Vellum, about 8 in. by 4 7/8, consisting of 66 leaves, the first three of which are slightly stained. The quires were 8 in number, but the first is now lost. They seem to have been originally signed with arithmetical figures (though the ciphers on foll. 1a and 12a are more recent), but the present signatures are letters. There are from 27 to 31 lines in each page. This manuscript is written in a beautiful, Edessene Estrangela, apparently of the vthcent.; with the exception of fol. 12, which was probably added by the same person who retouched foll. 1—3.

collation.p: They seem to have been originally signed with arithmetical figures.See additions.

item.p: The first three leaves are slightly stained.
The first quire is now lost.

layout.p: There are from 27 to 31 lines in each page.

handNote.desc: This manuscript is written in a beautiful, Edessene Estrangela, apparently of the5th century.

additions.note: N.B., folio location may not be available for some items below.

item.p: Fol. 12was probably added by the same person who retouchedfoll. 1—3.
Fol. 12 is palimpsest, the more ancient text being that of Jeremiah. See 2.
The ciphers on foll.1 aand12 aare more recent
The present signatures on the quires are letters.
Many lessons have been noted on the margins by later hands.

layout.p: There are from 27 to 31 lines in each page.

head.note: This manuscript contains: The Last Two Gospels, according to the Peshitta version. In total, including sub-sections, this manuscript contains 3 items.

listRelation.desc: This unit is a part of a composite manuscript:

msItem.title: The Last Two Gospels, according to the Peshitta version
msItem.finalRubric: ܫܠܡ ܠܡܟܬܒ ܒܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܐܘܢܓܠܣ̈ܛܐ ܬܪ̈ܝܢ ܠܘܩܐ. ܝܘܚܢܢ.

physDesc.p: Vellum, about 8 in. by 5, consisting of 103 leaves, the last 8 of which are much stained and soiled (Add. 14,459, foll. 67—169). The quires, 11 in number, seem to have been originally signed with arithmetical figures (though the ciphers on fol. 67 aare more recent), but the present signatures are letters (from ܛto ܝܛ). There are from 25 to 27 lines in each page. The writing is a small, elegant Estrangela of the vith cent, (between A.D. 530 and 540). Fol. 74 is a palimpsest leaf, probably added by the same person who retouched foll. 162 and 163.

collation.p: The quires, 11 in number, seem to have been originally signed with arithmetical figures.See additions.

item.p: The last 8 of the leaves are much stained and soiled.

layout.p: There are from 25 to 27 lines in each page.

handNote.desc: The writing is a small, elegant Estrangela ofthe 6th cent, (between A.D. 530 and 540).

decoNote.desc: Onfol. 67 athere is an ornamental Cross, containing the wordsܚܘܪ ܠܘܬܗ ܘܣܒܪ ܒܗ ܨܠܝܒܐ ܚܝܐin a comparatively modern hand.

additions.note: N.B., folio location may not be available for some items below.

item.p: The ciphers onfol. 67 aare more recent. The present signatures are letters (fromܛtoܝܛ).
Many lessons have been noted on the margins by later hands, sometimes in barbarous Greek (e. g. foll.94 a,105 b,107 b,110 b).
Fol. 74is a palimpsest leaf, probably added by the same person who retouched foll.162 and 163.
Fol. 74 is a palimpsest leaf of the9th or 10th century, the more ancient text being that ofS. Matthew.

item.label: Colophon
Doxology
item.p: On fol. 169 b we have the ordinary doxology; and under it, at some distance belowthe coloured ornament, there is a note, much injured and effaced, containing the date:

p.quote: ܐܫܬܠܡ ܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܒܝܪܚ . . . ܐܡܢܡܐܐ ܘܐܪ̈ܒܥܝܢ . . .
“This book was finished in the month of . . . ,(in the year) 84 . . (of the Greeks)," i. e.A.D. 53 . . .

item.p: From the remaining lines of the note it can be gathered that this manuscript was written at some person's expense, as a present to a church or monastery.

Of the later writing, with which the greater part of this page is covered, but little is distinctly legible. The name of a village called
Kěphar-Těkīrīn ܩܪܝܬܐ ܪܚܡܬ ܠܡܫܝܚܐ ܟܦܪ ܬܟܝܪܝܢ
occurs several times.

bibl.author: William Wright
bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

interpretation.p: Description is based on Wright's Catalogue without consultation of physical manuscripts. Foliation is approximate. Wright often does not indicate ending folia so those have been assumed based on beginning folia.
Scribal notes which could not be more clearly classified based on Wright's descriptions have been identified as <addition>s whether they occur in the margins or the body of the manuscript.
In general, we have classified as an <msItem> as much of the manuscript contents as possible, including tables of contents and indices.
